title.narrative: Study on Child Labour in the Arab States

description.narrative: The ILO estimates that 13.4 million, or about 15 percent, of all children in the Arab region are child labourers. The ILO also states that the real level of child labour may be much higher especially due to the predominance of child labour in the informal sector, which is usually difficult to measure. Moreover, many of the child labour estimates for the Arab States predate the Arab uprisings and the ensuing political upheaval, armed violence and massive population displacements of which the repercussions have been severe. The humanitarian and development actors are implementing in the region many programmes to supporting livelihoods of vulnerable households, upholding child protection, and preventing negative coping mechanisms hampering the child safety, But this is not enough to tackle comprehensively the concerning share of child labour in the region. Therefore, the aim of this study is to draw a road map to assist member states in formulating their future policies, develop strategies and programs for intervention to curb this seriously developing phenomenon. Its recent patterns include those resulting from Asylum, migration and exploitation of children during armed conflicts. These include but are not limited to children becoming victims of illicit activities like carrying and using arms to extreme exploitation in agricultural works, let alone other informal enterprises. The outcomes of the study should also be linked to the SDG 8.7 and the 2030 UN Agenda.
